items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

River levels are continuing to fall at Derwent Water. River levels are remaining high at the Lodore gauge. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwent Water and the frontage of the Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. No further significant rainfall is forecast. We expect to remove the flood warning later today. This message will be updated by 5:00PM on Thursday 10/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Derwent, Stonethwaite Beck and Derwent Water
items.message: Lake levels remain high but are slowly falling at Derwentwater following heavy rainfall over the last few days. Areas most at risk include low lying areas bordering the shores of Derwentwater and Keswick Camping and Caravan Club Site. No significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. River levels will start to fall at the Lodore gauge later today, Thursday 10/11/2022. Continue to avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00am on Friday 11/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

Levels are now below the flood risk thresholds. The forecast is for no current flood risk from high tides. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.message: The river levels in the area are continuing to fall, the lake level is slowly falling but will remain high for today. No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next few days. Continue to avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on Friday 11/11/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.60mAOD at 15:30 on 10/11/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are falling. The river flow at Teddington Weir is normal for this time of year at 65 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain normal for the next 2 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 18:00 on 10/11/22, or as the situation changes.

We will continue to monitor levels closely.

floodArea.county: Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole, Dorset Council

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the remainder of the week. We will continue to monitor the situation, and will re-issue this alert if necessary.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: Water levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the recent heavy rainfall. Consequently, there is a low risk of flooding to low-lying land and roads today, Thursday, 10/11/22. Locations most vulnerable to flooding are the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. River levels are falling, but still pose a flood risk. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low-lying footpaths and plan driving routes to avoid low-lying roads near rivers which may be flooded. Please refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 12:00 on Friday, 11/11/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast.

The River Uck is now falling all along its length. In Isfield, minor flood impacts affecting fields, gardens and rural roads will remain until Thursday, when the River Uck is expected to have returned to a more normal level. In Buxted and Uckfield, river levels are already nearer to normal. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week. Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast and will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: East Sussex, Kent, Surrey, West Sussex

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next 5 days.

The River Adur is high, but now slowly falling. Until approximately 16:00 Thursday 10/11/2022, minor flood impacts will affect fields, gardens and rural roads, including the A281 and gardens of riverside properties at Mock Bridge near Shermanbury. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, river levels are still unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until Sunday. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Water levels in the Eastern Yar remain high. In the past 24 hours a further 15mm of rain has been recorded at Wroxall. At Alverstone and Sandown, the river level is stabilising and will begin to fall in response to the rain recorded overnight. Today (Wednesday 9/11/22) some minor impact flooding of roads (including Golf Links and Moreton Common Road), and land is expected to continue. Isolated showers are forecast to continue into the evening (Wednesday 9/11/22). Whilst these showers may cause an increase in water level, property flooding is not expected. Additional rainfall may increase flood impacts on land, roads and possibly gardens. From Thursday (10/11/22), the weather remains dry and the situation will improve. We continue to monitor the forecast. We have been operating Bembridge sluice to help manage water levels at Brading Marshes. Please avoid walking, driving or cycling through ponded water. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 16:00 on Thursday 10/11/22.

The River Ouse is high between Scaynes Hill and Barcombe, but now slowly falling. Until approximately 16:00 on Thursday 10/11/2022, minor flood impacts will affect fields, gardens and rural roads, including at Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge and Barcombe Mills Road. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, in Barcombe, the River Ouse is still unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until Sunday. Closer to Ardingly, the River Ouse has already returned to a near normal level. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The Cuckmere River is high, but slowly falling in Alfriston. Minor flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel until approximately 16:00 on Thursday 10/11/2022. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, the Cuckmere River in Alfriston is unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until Sunday. In Hellingly, both the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers have already fallen significantly, and only minimal flood impacts are expected in Hellingly. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next 5 days.

Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding. No further significant rainfall is forecast for the next 5 days.

In Hellingly, both the Cuckmere and Bull Rivers are now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts should ease on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, Hellingly by Thursday (10/11/2022). A Flood Alert remains in force to inform of these minor flood impacts. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding in Hellingly on Wednesday evening. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. However, it is suggested that unsettled weather could return next week.  Please remain prepared for the risk of flooding to increase again after the weekend. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Warning if the risk of property flooding increases.

The River Ouse is high in Barcombe, but now slowly falling. Until approximately 16:00 Thursday 10/11/2022, minor flood impacts will affect fields, gardens and rural roads, including at Fletching Mill Bridge, Sharpsbridge and Barcombe Mills Road. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, in Barcombe, the River Ouse is still unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until Sunday. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The Cuckmere River is high, but slowly falling in Alfriston. Minor flooding will continue to affect locations near North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel until approximately 16:00 Thursday 10/11/2022. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, however, the Cuckmere River in Alfriston is unlikely to return nearer to a normal level until Sunday. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The Western Rother is still high in Fittleworth and at Lodsbridge near Selham. Minor flood impacts will continue in these locations, affecting fields, gardens, and rural roads. Water will also be very close to Fittleworth Mill and Lodsbridge Mill. At our Lodsbridge river level gauge, we think the Western Rother will begin to slowly fall by 22:00 on 09/11/2022. However, the river is unlikely to return nearer to normal levels until this weekend. The river may not fall significantly in Fittleworth until next week. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. Please keep property flood resilience measures installed at Lodsbridge near Selham until Thursday (10/11/2022), if you have them. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding, could return next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

The Langney Haven is high and rising over each high tide. The next tides at 23:45 on Wednesday (09/11/2022) and 12:00 on Thursday (10/11/2022) are forecast to be 20cm lower than Wednesday afternoon. However, minor flooding will continue to affect gardens of Langney Green. Fields and parkland including Shinewater Park could also be affected. The tide very early Friday morning (00:15 11/11/2022) is forecast to be 20cm lower again, and tides will continue to fall for the rest of the week. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. This will also allow the river level to very slowly fall through Langney. However, river levels are expected to remain higher than normal until next week. Please take proactive action to help reduce the impact of flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed at Langney Green, if you have them. We are operating our structures at Fence Bridge to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 21:00 10/11/2022.

Thursday’s very early morning tide at 00:00 on 10/11/2022 is forecast to be 20cm lower than recent days. The total forecast tide is 5.99 metres Chart Datum (2.94 mAOD) at Littlehampton. It will be accompanied by strong Westerly Force 5 winds, but smaller waves than recent days. Minimal flood impacts could still affect land and fields at Climping over high tide, but impacts should be less than recent days. Tide levels and flood risk will reduce for the rest of the week, with lighter winds and smaller waves. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels are continuing to fall on the River Roding in Abridge, Buckhurst Hill and Loughton following heavy rainfall over the last week. The risk of flooding to roads and low-lying land is now reducing. 
No further rainfall is forecast today.  The forecast for the remainder of the week until Saturday is dry. 
We recommend that you avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses as there may still be standing water in some locations. 
Our incident response staff are monitoring the situation and taking action where necessary. We recommend that you remain aware of the forecast for the next 5 days.

The Aldingbourne Rife is high, but very slowly falling near Shripney, Bersted and Felpham. Flood water will continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259. It is likely flood water will also affect parts of the Tesco car park on Shripney Road, as well as land at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry. This will allow the river level to fall further through Bersted. However, river levels will fall extremely slowly and are expected to remain higher than normal through to next week. No flood impacts are currently expected in Barnham, where river levels have already fallen significantly from their peak. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 11:00 on 11/11/2022.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message: The risk of flooding in the Rivers Clyst and Culm Area has now reduced. River levels are falling below levels of concern, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Showers are forecast for Wednesday 9th and Thursday 10th November, and river levels will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teign, River Bovey, River Lemon, River Kenn

items.message: The risk of flooding in the River Teign Area has now reduced. River levels are falling below levels of concern, however there may be standing water seen for several days. Showers are forecast for Wednesday and Thursday and river levels will remain sensitive to any further rainfall. Take care near the areas of concern and monitor your local weather conditions.

The River Arun at Pulborough is high, but slowly falling. The next five days are currently predicted to remain dry, which will allow the River Arun to fall further. Tide levels at Littlehampton will also fall. Although flooding will still be extensive through fields, with water levels falling, flood impacts affecting properties will slowly reduce in Pulborough, Amberley and Houghton. Please be aware that it is possible further wet weather and a risk of flooding could return next week. We will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding to properties increases.

Thursday’s very early morning tide at 00:00 on 10/11/2022 is forecast to be 30cm lower than recent days. The total forecast tide is 4.88 metres Chart Datum (2.14 mAOD) at Chichester Harbour. It will be accompanied by strong Westerly Force 5 winds. The tide will still flood Shore Road, Bosham, but should not affect Bosham High Street. Tide levels and flood risk will reduce for the rest of the week, with lighter winds and smaller waves. We will continue to monitor the levels and forecast, and we will re-issue this message if the risk of flooding increases again.

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames

items.message:
River levels in the River Crane have been falling steadily over the last 24 hours.  It is now expected that the Crane tidal gates will be able to close and hold back the incoming tide. 
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected in the Haliburton Road, Eve Road and Talbot Road area, however, there may be areas of standing water that will slowly drain away over the next few days. 
No further rainfall is expected for the next few days.
We will continue to monitor the river level and observe weather forecasts and will issue any new flood messages when needed.
This message will automatically be removed after 10 days.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop.   
No further rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high.
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 19:00 on 10/11/2022, or as the situation changes.
